title: Match statement requires impossible to reach code/cases for clamped integer types
body:
It seems that rust requires the handling of all cases in match statement even if the integer type is constricted or clamped such as in `match a & 0b11` , where the integer being matched must be , 0, 1, 2, or 3. I do understand that rust promotes the idea of accounting for all possible cases of a type in a match statement, but this particular scenario requires one to write unreachable code, which seems like a bug:

I tried this code:

```rust
   let a = 0b11010;
   match a & 0b11 {
       0b0 => println!("got 0!"),
       0b1 => println!("got 1!"),
       0b10 => println!("got 2!"),
       0b11 => println!("got 3!")
   }
```

I expected to see this happen: *I expected the code to function normally and write "got 2!" to the terminal*

Instead, this happened: * I got the below error*

```rust
error[E0004]: non-exhaustive patterns: `i32::MIN..=-1_i32` and `4_i32..=i32::MAX` not covered
 --> src/main.rs:4:10
  |
4 |    match a & 0b11 {
  |          ^^^^^^^^ patterns `i32::MIN..=-1_i32` and `4_i32..=i32::MAX` not covered
  |
  = help: ensure that all possible cases are being handled, possibly by adding wildcards or more match arms
  = note: the matched value is of type `i32`
```
